titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Answered Dr: Edwards’s letter, and began one to the Secretary of State. Weather better than yesterday, and find myself more capable of application. But spite of my two daily walks, my health will not bend to my perpetual attention. met Reuterswerd in the Voorhout this Evening.

2. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. Our Master appears to interest himself very much in the progress of the french. There is here a man with whom he consorts; an author; who being acquainted with the Geography of Lower Saxony his native Country, offers his services as a guide to the french troops now invading that territory, to conduct them where the richest plunder is to be obtained. Noël is therefore going to send him to the army of the Rhine. Bielfeld thinks the morality of the man rather inaccurate, but says he is abon diable, and that it is not avarice but fanaticism that inspires him. I believe it is the fanaticism of the followers of Catiline and Cethegus.— Walk in the wood.— Evening at the Dutch play.Menschenhaat and en Berouw (Misanthropy and Repentance.) a translation from a German Comedy of Kotzebue. The Misanthropy, is that of an husband, whose beloved wife has been seduced by a young man, and has eloped with him. The Repentance is that of the wife, for having been seduced, and her consequent elopement. It closes with a reconciliation. Bingley was very good in the husband, and Mademoiselle, bating a little too much roaring in her lamentations excellent in Ulalia the wife. From her performance she should more properly have been called Ulularia. I cannot forgive Pratt for comparing her with Mrs: Siddons. For the nice delicate shades that distinguish similar Passions she is altogether incompetent, and she knows little more than how to weep and wail and gnash her teeth. Her performances are therefore very monotonous. Bingley has the same fault though not in the same degree. Yet this Evening and the former they beguiled me of some tears, and received the same tribute from many others. The house was full The play is very long. I know not how many acts it pretends to have; but the natural divisions give it six or seven.— The farce, a translation from Jacques Spleen, I did not stay to hear half thro’ though Bingley performed the principal character. It was late, and I was weary.

3. Letters this morning.— Mr: Skipwith writes Mr: Beeldemaker, that a cruiser of Tunis has taken an American vessel. Is this a new political false alarm, or has the business not been well done Time will shew. Finished the translation of Ovid’s Metamorphoses. It is very unequal, being the work of many hands. In general it preserves the turn of wit and quaintness of the original. The want of proper concatenation is a defect belonging to the poem too. And the pathetic powers, for which there was so much room were in a great measure strangers to a mind which is always toiling for a conceit. The most striking part of the work to me, was the speeches of Ajax and Ulysses in their contest for the arms of Achilles at the beginning of the 13th: Book. They are highly characteristic and dramatical.— I have remarked in the course of this reading the source of a great number of Shakespeare’s allusions and ideas. I remember the writer of his life mention Sandys’s Ovid as one of the books from whence he gathered the little learning he ever had.

4. My time very steadily and constantly employed. The principal objection remaining in my mind, at present against the distribution of it is, that too much of it is devoted to pursuits not directly connected with my station. Began reading this afternoon Hoole’s translation of the Jerusalem delivered. Went to the Dutch play; and saw “Fenelon or the nuns of Cambrai—a translation from Chenier. Revolutionary, and like the Zoë destined to make the confinement of a nunnery odious— Bingley
performed the part of the Archbishop, and Mademoiselle Wattier that of Héloïse. It was for her benefit, and the last time of their performing here at present. Had occasion to make again most of the remarks of the preceding Evenings. The farce “Cange or the Cryer of Lazaret.”— entirely Dutch and completely dull. Met Schermerhorn in coming out of the house.

5. Resumed the reading of Kerroux’s History, which I have been obliged for some days to suspend. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s— Short walk in the woods afterwards, where I met Mr: Levsen, and I believe a brother of Madame de Schubart.— The Baron has been very ill of a fever and is now slowly recovering. Read this afternoon Hoole’s life of Tasso at the head of his translation. A romantic life indeed. Born 1544. and died 1595. Settled by an examination a scruple that arose in my mind upon a fact mentioned by the biographers of Milton, that he was when in Italy acquainted with Manso, Marquis of Villa the intimate friend of Tasso and his patron. My doubts arose from the distance of time between the two sublime Poets, and from an idea taken from one of the biographers that Manso is celebrated in the Gierusalemme Liberata. This poem was finished and published in 1574. Milton was in Italy, about 1638. A period of sixty-eight years, appeared long for the life of a man already of an age to be celebrated as a magnanimous knight.— I ascertained however that it was really the same man, by turning to the Latin Poem which Milton addressed to him. But it is in the Jerusalem Conquered that Tasso mentions Manso. this Poem, was published only three or four years before the Death of the Italian bard. Walk in the Evening. Met Bielfeld. Conversation with him. He made some observations upon the curious practice of fabricating books, in Germany at this time. There is a sort of literary mania prevalent there. His literary Cethegus has told him some new anecdotes upon that subject. At the last semi-annual Fair of Leipzig, an hundred and seventy nine new Novels made their appearance.— He mentioned too the smothered flame of democracy, as burning with great fury in every part of Germany, and especially in the Danish Dominions.

6. Received this morning a large packet of Letters from England, and America. Among others one from the Secretary of State dated June 11. informing me that I was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to Portugal, but directing me to remain here untill I receive further orders. Wrote several letters.— At the french play this Evening. “Raoul de Crequi”— “La famille indigente,[”] a poor thing in every respect. Met Bielfeld there.

7. Wrote a couple of letters. Mr: Parker, paid us a visit. Came from Utrecht this morning, and returns there to night.— Miss’d the lesson of Italian—indeed I have been obliged to supersede yesterday and this day my attention to this study. I may perhaps find it necessary to suspend it entirely, at least for the present. The circumstance mentioned yesterday, gives an entire new turn to my affairs, and presents new objects which must command my immediate application— Walk in the wood. Met Levsen, Bielfeld, and our instructor whose name is Buchner— My brother went to dine at Mr: Beeldemaker’s seat in the Country, and to Rotterdam at night.

8. Received letters this forenoon from Mr: Pinckney, and from Mr: Pitcairn. Leyden Gazette. Affairs requiring attention crowd upon me. I must soon change my objects of occupation perhaps entirely; and have more occasion for much time than ever. Met Mr: Levsen in my morning walk, and again in the Voorhout, this Evening. Had then a long conversation with him on the present State of European affairs. His hint of the propriety that there should be Ministers between the United States and Denmark. Met Bielfeld, with Buchner and the literary Jacobin Reissman, who set out yesterday for Paris, but some how or other came back, and is going again to-morrow.

9. Lesson of Italian this morning, but was not prepared for it, being busily employed in writing letters. Rather unwell.— My health always draws limits round my application. Bielfeld called on me towards Evening. We walked to Scheveling. Enquired of him to whom the dispatches of the Prussian Ministers were addressed. He says directly to the king. The rescripts are directly from him. The late king always wrote the answers himself. The present king has them brought to him ready to sign, in cypher with the explanation on a different paper. If he thinks of any alteration he inserts it on the explanation but signs the cypher, which is then sent away just as it was.— A curious specimen of diplomacy.

10. Visit this morning from Mr: Van Dyck, a Gentleman born at Ghent, but long resident in this Country, and admitted a Councillor of the Court of Holland and Zealand. He is dissatisfied, with the present order of things: has a large family, and with some of his friends has thoughts of going to America. His object was to make enquiries concerning that Country.— Lesson of Italian, instead of that which we lost on Sunday. Met Mr: Araujo and Mr: Levsen in the Voorhout. Long walk with them: particularly the former. He is a man of great information, and especially conversant in general literature. Made some enquiries with respect to Portugal. He mentioned among many other things that the famous Methuen Treaty of 1703. Was made by a Portugueze Minister so totally ignorant of every thing relative to Commerce; that about a year after he wrote to the Minister of that Court then residing here, a letter in which he speaks to this purport “By the way. I forgot to tell you in my preceding dispatches, that we made last year a little Treaty (Trattadino) with England, in which she agrees to take our wines, and we to take her woollens. Try and see if you can make such an one with the Dutch.” The Chevalier says he found this letter among the archives of the legation. The same Minister did not know that in the English Parliament there had already been debates upon the subject of admitting the wines of Portugal, upon the same terms as they are by the Treaty without any stipulation whatever.— The Treaty was agreed to by the Dutch, only for the asking.— M: d’Araujo has no great opinion of the commercial abilities of Lord Auckland.— Says that the commercial Treaty with France, upon which his fame first originated was the work of Mr: Crawford.— That at the time when G. Britain and Russia, were at the point of War, Auckland asked him one day what way the troops were to be sent to assist the Turks against the Russians.

11. This afternoon old Moreau came to tell me, that Mr: Dumas had within an hour before fallen dead in the street. I went immediately to see his wife. She talked about her affliction, but appeared to be thinking about any thing else. They lived very indifferently together, and the loss will not cost her many tears of grief.— I once loved and respected this Man. Let me remember only that period when he was my friend and instructor. His last days were very wretched, and his misery proceeded from his own political opinions and their discordancy with those of others. A great part of the misery which the human race now suffers arises from the variance of political opinions.

12. Writing very steadily all the forenoon. Excepting only the time of our Italian lesson. Weather warm, and extremely dull and heavy. Met Mr: Levsen, and M. d’Araujo this Evening in the Voorhout— Walk with them.— Bielfeld mentioned to me a curious taste of M. Noël, the french Minister; that of collecting
Manuscript copies of all sorts of lascivious tales in verse, from printed books.— Our Italian instructor is almost constantly employed by him at this sort of copying; and he is very scrupulous and nice to have the hand-writing neat and elegant. I remember that among the books which I brought from England for him, were a number of volumes manuscript, of this description.— I now wish I had examined a little further the character of those books.— I did not however then imagine, that he was the man, whose relish for the rankest forces of literature was so keen. Before the revolution of France a clergyman, and professor of Eloquence at the College of Louis le Grand in the University of Paris: since that period, employed in high rank among their diplomatic negotiators. I did not suspect him of a propensity so ill-sorted, with his old profession as well as with his new station. By what strange sort of beings the affairs of the world are managed.

13. Continue busily employed in writing, so that I have almost abandoned all reading for the present. Find a difficulty of application even to that which I still continue.— The eye or the voice reads, but the mind receives nothing. This is one of the infirmities which I often find it impossible to remove. The dull relaxing weather of the dog-days contributes towards it; and for some days past I have almost found a physical impossibility to rise at my hour prescribed. Hitherto the effort of the will has so far overpowered the weakness of the flesh, that I have not broken my rule of rising. But I have not yet obtained the complete controul of my application. I fear I never shall.— Walk before dinner. At the french play this Evening. “Othello, ou le More de Venise.” A wretched travestie by Ducis from Shakespeare’s Othello, with most of his defects, and innumerable others with scarce one of his beauties. It has the merit however of containing sarcasms upon aristocracy, and abuse upon the Government of Venice.— Othello, was tawny but not black.— The performance was worse than the play. Bielfeld and I did not stay to hear the famille indigente a second time, but closed the Evening with a walk together in the Voorhout.— Visit this morning from the french Minister Noël. He says the french Consuls at Amsterdam and Rotterdam both write him that they have violent suspicions that some Captains of American vessels, engage on board of them, french soldiers belonging to the army of the North. He desired me therefore to request of the Agents of the United States in those places to prevent any practice of that kind in future, and further wished me to authorise the french officers to visit the vessels, to discover whether any french soldiers were concealed in them. I told him that I had no power to authorise any person to visit or examine American vessels, and if I should pretend to assume it the American Captains would certainly not recognize it, but that I would readily write to the Consul at Amsterdam and request him to discourage as much as possible every such practice, and to recommend the discharge of any persons who may have been thus engaged.— Wrote to Mr: Bourne accordingly.

14. Letter again from Messrs: Condy and Co: of Charleston. Answered it. Lesson of Italian. Short walk after it with Bielfeld. Met Mr: Levsen and my brother— Our Italian Instructor has anecdotes of abuse to tell against Madame Dumas. Told him after he had related one of them that I did not believe it. Where did he get his anecdotes. They were told him by a Jew, an eye witness he said.— I told him I did not believe them true, notwithstanding.— La calomnie— The french Statesmen of the present day are disciples of Basile, in the Barbier de Seville.— Walk again in the Evening. Met M: d’Araujo, in the Voorhout.
Mr: N. Van Staphorst called on me this afternoon. Conversation with him upon our affairs. He came from Amsterdam yesterday, but the bankers had not yet received my last Letter.— Says they received the last week, a satisfactory letter from the Secretary of the Treasury. Mentions that an American Captain, who arrived a few days since told them he was boarded by an Officer of a british Man of War, who after examining his papers told him that if the principal part of the Cargo had been laden, by an house the name of which was on a small invoice, he should have carried him in, because that house was one of a list which he had, and who were known to lend their names to cover property. Mr: Van Staphorst did not appear to relish this. He asked why American Merchants could not lend their names as the Danish Government lends its flag and is known to do so.— I told him that the question of free ships, free goods, was by our Treaty with Britain left precisely where it was before, and that we had not conceded it, to which he agreed.

15. All the forenoon again writing closely. but the weather almost overpowers me.— Finished reading the Lettres familieres et autres du Baron de Bielfeld. He was a courtier, and not a very profound thinker. His son says that one of the great advantages of reading his works is that they cost not the smallest effort of the mind. At least one half of these volumes consists of descriptions either of Palaces and Gardens belonging to the king and Princes of Prussia, or of festivals and ceremonial parades upon princely marriages and other similar occasions. It They contain also many particulars of his private life. He was by birth a Hamburger, and attached himself to the late king of Prussia, before his accession to the throne. Soon after this Event, which is detailed in one of the letters with the true Spirit of a Courtier, he was employed as Secretary to a legation at the Court of George the 2d: at Hanover: he afterwards went to England in the same capacity. He spent some time there, but his letters written from thence do not shew that he became very intimately acquainted with the Nation. Two of them however are interesting; the one upon the question as to the benefits of civilization, which Rousseau, has since made so famous, and the other containing a sort of historical dissertation upon Romance and novel writers ancient and modern. On his return from England, where he was not many months, he was placed as a counsellor in the department of foreign affairs. He was afterwards appointed Governor of the king’s youngest brother Ferdinand. Upon his marriage the king made him a Baron, and Curator of all the Prussian Universities.— He probably found some time after his style of living too expensive, and retired altogether from the Court of Berlin to an Estate in Saxony called Treben. Here he was routed by the contending parties in the seven years war, and retired to Hamburg where the last Letters are dated in 1760. The volumes are dedicated to Voltaire in an Epistle rather too encomiastic. The last years, are embittered by misfortune; his property suffered by fire and the sword; and he lost a number of children successively in their infancy. The book will not add much to the wisdom or Virtue of any one, but it may amuse the leisure of a few hours. I am particular in this account chiefly on account of the intimacy I have formed with his son which has added much to the interest I take in his history.
Called this Evening to see Madam Dumas. Walk afterwards alone in the Voorhout.

16. Lesson of Italian. I shall soon abandon this Study. Evening at the Play. Jaques Spleen, an old story. Oedipe à Colone. exquisite music of Sacchini, and performed more tolerably than the custom of the Company. Better amused than I have been at any exhibition before, since I came from England. Walk afterwards with Bielfeld and our Italian Master.
17. In bed till 7. Very industrious to repair the lost time. Of course over laboured. Solitary walking.— Day almost wholly devoted to writing.

18. My health suffers. perhaps from a life too sedentary. Night indifferent. But returned to the hour of six. Letter from the bankers at Amsterdam. answered it. Afternoon went to see Madam Veerman. Found her sincerely afflicted at the Death of her father. Couple of hours there. Returning in the boat, had the company of a french officer, a lawyer and a student at Leyden. The first appeared extremely desirous of Peace.— The lawyer regretted the expence of his education at Leyden. The student told me there were at this time about 290 students at this University, of whom one hundred for the law, the same number in Physic and about ninety and in divinity. The number is much diminished within a few years.— He said that at Utrecht the number was about 350. at Harlingen and Franeker very few. At Harderwyk about twelve or fourteen.

19. Up at half past five. Dullness, languor, universal stagnation of spirits. Lesson of Italian. Walk with Bielfeld and Mr: Levsen— Went to look at some books that are to be sold. Began to read an Histoire de la conspiration de Louis-Philippe Joseph d’Orléans, nommé Egalite. in 3 volumes. Appears to be a poor thing. Walk alone in the Evening.

20. Begin to be relieved from the burden of writing that has pressed on me these three weeks, and hope to have again some time for reading. Met Mr: Levsen in my morning walk. Dined at Mr: Araujo’s. Reuterswerd, Levsen, Bielfeld, & my brother.— At the play in the Evening. Eustache Pointu. Well enough. Le tyran corrigé. Indifferently performed. Walk with Bielfeld round the town after the play. Weather very fine.

21. Weather very warm. Having a little leisure upon my hands, began to read Murphy’s travels in Portugal. Not much information to be acquired in them. Lesson of Italian. Mr: Walker from Rotterdam, dined with us.— Letter from Mr: Bourne.

22. Mr: Godfrey, Captain Nickerson, and Mr Stetson called here this morning for Passports to go to America. A new law of the National Assembly requires every person going from the Country should have a Passport from them. Went to see Mr: Van Leyden, who told me that it did not apply to the citizen of any foreign power having a Passport from his Minister, and therefore not to any Citizen of the U. States having my Passport. Gave them accordingly.— Attended a sale of books. But interrupted from it, by these People. Weather extremely warm. Walk in the Evening. Met M. d’Araujo

23. Received from Hamburg a Packet containing New-York news-papers to June 25th: and a sett of the Laws of the last Session of Congress.— The newspapers, affect as usual. the prosperous period for
for America, seems to be nearly past. Its futurity looks darker from day to day.— Lesson of Italian. Visit from Reuterswerd.— Attended the sale but again not at due times. Walk in the Evening, met M. Araujo.— He thinks it impossible to govern Europe by proconsuls, at the present day.

24. Captain Nickerson, and Stetson, came back again for their Passports with a letter from Godfrey, upon which I found it hard to keep my temper. The Committee of internal correspondence at Amsterdam, insist that there must be a Passport from the Assembly; and declare that the Secretary of the Committee for foreign affairs has nothing to say or do in the business.— This is equality, if not fraternity.— Went again to see Mr: Van Leyden, who says it must be a misconstruction of the Amsterdam Committee. Saw the President of the Committee of internal correspondence with him again, he is decidedly of the same opinion and promised to write a letter to the Amsterdam Committee to obviate all difficulty for the future. But in order that these persons who are in a great hurry to sail may not be detained while the thing is explaining, I requested Passports of the Assembly, for them. But Mr: Van Leyden, as well as the President and Secretary of the Committee of internal correspondence assured me it would be unnecessary.— Attended the debates of the Assembly.— and the sale.

25. At length have a moment of relief. Again at the sale of books. Finished this morning the translation of the life of Agricola, by Tacitus. I translated the same work into french in the year 1784. It merits a very particular attention— Walk to Scheveling.— Finished reading Hoole’s translation of Tasso.— The book is popular. The versification is very smooth; but it appears to be feeble. It is cold, and has been read like a task, and of course with very little attention. I have compared most of the first book with the original. The sense is diluted. The poetic charm the soul of the verse is in many instances lost, or rather is in very few preserved. But when Tasso is robbed of this attraction he has but little left. His invention is wretchedly poor and strangely absurd. His machinery is pitiful. But his details of sentiment, character and language are admirable. “La Poésie says Voltaire, ne plait que par les beaux details.” This is a very mean and false idea of Poetry, but it suits the delicate tenuity of a french critic, and is just calculated to place The Henriade or the Jerusalem above the Iliad, and the Zaïre above the Othello. Upon this maxim the poem of Tasso would be superior to any production of the epic Muse till the days of Voltaire. Tasso excels very much in his female characters. His Sophronia, Clorinda, Erminia, Gildippe, and even Armida, are all extremely interesting. The Gerusalemme therefore is above all others the Epic Poem of the Ladies.— Homer’s Andromache stands alone, and bears a very subordinate part. His Penelope though much praised excites little attention. All the rest are either obnoxious, or
have so little agency that they are not to be mentioned.— Virgil is noted for his severity to the fair sex. He seems to delight in aggravating their infirmities & insulting their misfortunes. Milton has but one female. But alas! Hinc illae lacrymae. She is the instrument which

lg.l: “Brought Death into the world, and all our woe.”

div.p: Lucan’s Cornelia though respectable is employed in little else besides lamentation, and Voltaire’s Belle Gabrielle is not much better than his Agnes Sorel. But all that is tender, generous and amiable as well as brave is united in the heroines of Tasso. Their adventures comprehend the most pleasing parts of the whole poem, and indeed there is scarce any part of it, but in which some one or more of them appears.— The story of Edward and Gildippe is upon the model of Nisus and Euryalus, but is much more affecting, to a chaste Imagination. Armida, is a composition of Calypso of Circe and of Dido, and a great improvement upon them all. Erminia has some traits in common with Helen, but is much her superior, as is Clorinda to Camilla.— Sophronia appears to be an original, and is a very pleasing one.— One of the great advantages which this Poem, has over those of antiquity, arises from the superior manners. There is a refinement of passion and a delicacy of sentiment, which can be attributed only to the operation of the precepts of Christianity upon the human character. The loving passions of antiquity were coarse; their hatred was implacable.— Achilles restored the body of Hector to Priam; but that was from a motive of generosity when he felt no resentment. at all other times he was unrelenting. The Pious AEneas is equally inflexible to the compunctious visitings of nature; but Tancred and Rinaldo are both merciful and generous to their vanquished enemies.— Their love is gentle and their anger is humane. This is one of the benefits of Christianity the most clearly evident, as the revolution of manners is indubitable, and can be traced to no other source, while it naturally flows from that.— Mr: Hoole has omitted some of the concetti, from which Boileau inferred that Tasso was all tinsel. There are too many of them in the original, but from such defects what modern Poet is altogether exempt.— I ought to have finished this book two days ago. As the weight of the task encreased, I felt my disposition to slip from under it grow upon me, and I have omitted the work of two days.

26. Last day of the sale. attended it in the morning. Lesson of Italian; but this study is neglected with most of the rest.— Observations on the life of Agricola. Began to read Milton’s Paradise Lost; with the pleasure we feel at meeting an old valuable acquaintance whom we have long, not seen.— A few minutes at the National Assembly. Debates not of consequence.

27. My books came home, and crowd me excessively.— Short walk in the forenoon. Evening at the play. La Caverne, an Opera taken from Gilblas. Music of Le Sueur. Indifferent, and poorly performed.— Walk with Bielfeld after the play. Overtaken by the rain. When I came home found Cashmore, in the house.— He was in great distress to go to Embden, three days ago. The fellow must be a swindler, or worse.

28. Visit this morning from Mr: Schermerhorn. I suspect he has the habit of promising more than he can perform. Lesson of Italian.— Rainy day. Endeavoured to walk this Evening, but overtaken with by the rain was obliged to return home. Idled much of the time.
29. Endeavouring to make some arrangement of my books. Walk to Scheveling alone this afternoon. Looked wistfully across the water, as far as I could ken.— in vain.

30. Time again spent in arranging books. Late at Bielfeld’s for the lesson of Italian: it is now by my neglect reduced principally to reading a few stanza’s of Tasso. Our instructor indeed, teaches us as Gilblas’s uncle taught him latin. I believe he learns himself as much as he imparts to us.— Walk with Bielfeld. Again in the evening. Notwithstanding which, had an indifferent night, and bad rest.

31. Rainy day at intervals. Walk however before dinner, and again at the commencement of the Evening. Obliged by the rain to return. Weather heavy and sultry— Waked in the night by the violence of the rain.

Monthly day. The first half of this month was very industrious. especially in writing. I have seldom been during the same length of time so steadily and constantly employed. my rising hour was about half past 5, and did not once exceed 6. Began the day by translating a page of Tacitus. then letter writing till half past 9. Breakfast. Letter writing again with Italian lesson till half-past two. Walk. Dinner. reading till dark. Evening walk, and retired about 11.— Pleasant as this course was to my mind, my health would not submit to it, and the last half of the month has been loose and relaxed. The dog-day temperature spreads a lifeless languor over the spirits, irresistible to me. It overcomes my Patience, so that upon Buffon’s maxim, I have no genius. My rising hour has retrograded to a vibration from 6 to 7. It threatens to become still more indulgent to indolence. The attention to Tacitus however has not been intermitted. In reviewing the Agricola my progress is slower than it was in translating. I am not always able to write a page in the course of the morning labour before breakfast, and it now engrosses all that period. Between that and dinner time I am falling into the habit of whiling away the time; in any thing that can serve as an apology for idleness. The afternoon is not much better, and generally persists only in the epic perusal, in which the two last days have been recovered. The days are rapidly shortening and the evening will soon be unfavourable for walking. It is already much less inviting to that effect, and I begin to prefer taking the necessary exercise before dark. I cannot therefore always avoid trespassing a little upon the Evening for study. The morning Muse of History, and the Evening Muse of Epic song, are now my only constant attendants: all the rest are abandoned or have only an occasional moment of attention.— The particular attention I am beginning to devote to Tacitus, is not without its reason. I must be thorough Master of that writer if I have any patience.

Have therefore in the course of this month read only Bielfeld’s letters; part of the Histoire de la Conspiration du Duc d’Orleans, half a volume of Kerroux’s history of Holland: finished the translation of the metamorphoses, and gone through Hoole’s translation of Tasso’s Jerusalem, with some books of Milton’s Paradise lost. It will be well if the reading of the next month should be even upon a level with this.
